title: Can displaced Anguilla marmorata return to their original habitat? Daily tracking study of their homing behavior
content:
Abstract

Anguilla marmorata collected in the Odana River lower reaches were passive integrated transponder-tagged displaced and released into the upper river reaches (54 up-transported eels), and eels collected in the upper reaches were tagged and released downstream (52 down-transported eels). Their movements were detected once per day for 10â€‰days using a portable radio-frequency identification (RFID) system. The homing rate of the down-transported eels was 38.9%, compared to 3.7% for the up-transported eels, suggesting that eels inhabiting upstream areas have relatively high fidelity to their habitats and downstream eels have less fidelity.
author:
Tatsuhiko Maeda, 
Seishi Hagihara, 
Ryoshiro Wakiya, 
Shingo Kimura
